awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of hierarchical control in skilled action sequencing
awd_abstract_narration:
A critical issue in cognitive science is understanding how behavior unfolds in time. Most human behaviors, from walking and talking, to driving, typing and playing instruments, consist of a series of ordered actions. Little is known concerning how people learn the serial ordering of actions and how this ability changes with expertise. This investigation uses the task of skilled typing to study how high- and low-level cognitive processes interact to allow typists to order their keystrokes rapidly and accurately. Typing is a useful model system for this purpose because experts are plentiful and typing performance can be measured precisely in terms of keystroke timing and errors. Prior studies have shown that typing skill is controlled hierarchically by two processing loops: an "outer loop" turns ideas into words and sentences and an "inner loop" translates words into motor movements for executing individual keystrokes. Three related projects test how these loops control serial ordering across levels of typing skill. Project 1 uses a large-scale web-based approach to quantify how novices and experts become sensitive to the statistics of natural keystrokes and learn to optimize typing performance for predictable letter patterns. Project 2 explores how the inner loop becomes gradually connected to the outer loop, allowing verbal codes used for language production to control serial ordering of fingers on the keyboard. Project 3 tests how the inner loop schedules the timing of individal keystrokes after it has received word-level instructions from the outer loop. 

Typing, especially on computers and smartphones, has become an indispensable modern skill. This work can provide new statistical signatures of typing skill that can be used to promote rapid skill acquisition. The science of typing can also serve as a model for investigating other domains that rely on hierarchical control loops to accomplish complex serial ordering, such as playing a musical instrument, assembly work, and interactive technologies. The project also provides training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at an institution that serves several minority and underrepresented groups.

por.por_cntn:
Cognition in the service of meaningful performance (walking, talking, driving, typing, playing music, etc.) requires coordination of planning, perceiving, learning, attending, and remembering processes to produce goal-driven action sequences. The broad research aims of this grant were to contrast two theoretical approaches to the coordination of action sequencing, using the domain of skilled typing on a computer keyboard. Skilled typing is a convenient research tool because experts are plentiful, and task performance in terms of keystroke speed and accuracy can be recorded precisely. The grant aims addressed two dominant theoretical perspectives about cognitive processes controlling sequential action. On the one hand, skilled action sequencing may emerge from general learning and memory processes that become sensitive to the statistical structure of action sequences, and may optimize performance by tuning into that structure. On the other hand, skilled action sequencing may be coordinated by interconnected processing modules that take care of specific action sequencing functions, such as planning a sequence, buffering action elements, and executing action elements in a desired order. There were several positive outcomes, described in terms of intellectual merit and broader impacts below.

 

Intellectual merit

We determined whether variation in typists' keystrokes for individual letters could be explained by statistical structure in letters and letter sequences (letter pairs and triples) from natural text. Using a large sample of typists, we found clear positive evidence that typing times are highly sensitive to letter and sequence predictability, as measured by large digitized corpuses of natural language. We also developed a computational model explaining how a general learning and memory process can account for performance that depends on learning regularities from the environment. These findings bolster evidence favoring the role of general learning and memory processes in controlling action sequencing, and provide a model that can be generalized outside of the domain of typing to explain how performance is constrained by statistical properties of the action environment in other domains. 

Another major contribution was to create novel behavioral and neuro-behavioral measurement techniques to assess moment-to-moment dynamics of response scheduling during the act of typing. For example, one major issue is to understand how people control the activation of a future response while they are executing a current response. Upcoming actions need to be actively managed so they are not executed in the incorrect order. Using tools such as transcranial magnetic stimulation, and motor evoked potentials from fingertips, we were able to create direct measures of action plan activation during an online typing task. Our findings provided novel support for competitive cueing models of response scheduling, and we are optimistic these research methods will become more widely used in performance research.

 

Broader impacts

The completed work was primarily aimed at a basic science level, using the real-world performance task of skilled typing to adjudicate between general and specialized process models of action sequencing. Broader impacts of the research for society include specific and general impacts. Our findings contribute to the science of typing, which is an important modern skill. Our open data provides new behavioral signatures of typing expertise, in the form of individual-level keystroke dynamic characteristics (how fast people type specific letters in specific contexts). These typing "biometrics" can be used to identify hallmarks of typing expertise, which can improve pedagogy for optimizing typing expertise, and the time needed to learn to type. Our most recent findings show that keystroke dynamics can be decoded to classify cognitive states, such as a person's attitudes toward the semantic content of the text they are typing. These findings will be relevant to the development of algorithms for deception and plagiarism detection, based on written digital correspondence. More broadly, the research engaged a postdoc, graduate and undergraduate students, including several under-represented minority students, who have been trained in behavioral research skills including running large N, online behavioral experiments, and computational modelling techniques. The project included an extensive data-sharing initiative. All research findings can be accessed by the public through the lab website, pre-print services, and online repositories that share the data, and the analysis scripts using open-software. Finally, the development of methods and workflow for sharing research findings, led to synergistic activities, such as using the same research-sharing tools to create free, open educational resources, in the form of undergraduate research methods and introductory statistics textbook for training a wider body of students in skills for conducting psychological research.
